question: She hasn't had a thing yesterdayor today.
answer: Been sending her meals in regularly?

question: Yessir. She refuses them all. It's not quite that simple.
answer: Absurd!

question: This is dangerous business, Mr. Andrews. After all, kidnapping is no child's play.
answer: What's this! What's happened here? Get another tray ready. Bring it here at once.

question: What's this! What's happened here? Get another tray ready. Bring it here at once.
answer: What do you want?

question: What's this about not eating? Know what my next move is? No more cigarettes.
answer: Why don't you put me in chains?

question: I might. Yes? Wait a minute! Don't get excited! This isn't for you. No. Everything seems quite satisfactory. I may want some more of that delicious gravy. I'll ring.
answer: You can't tempt me. I hope you're not comparing yourself to Napoleon. He was a strategist. Your idea of strategy is to use a lead pipe.

question: We leave Miami in an hour. Soon's we get some supplies aboard. I'll get it annulled.
answer: You'll never do it! You can't do it!

question: Nothing much. I just think he's a fake, that's all.
answer: You only met him once .

question: That was enough. Do you mind handing me the ketchup?
answer: You talk as if he were a gigoloor something.

question: You're going to finance him, I suppose.
answer: Why not? Look what he's doing for aviation. It takes courage to do what he does. And character! At least he's accomplished something worthwhile. I suppose you'd like to have me marry a business man. Well, I hate business menparticularly if you're a shining example. Your whole life is devoted to just one thing. To accumulate more money. At least there's romance in what he's doing.

question: Please don't shout.
answer: I'll shout to my heart's content! I'll scream if I want to.

question: Scram. Personally, I was raised on a bottle. Ohthe papers
answer: Hey, whadda you tryin' to dokid me?

question: Oh, I wouldn't kid you . On the level, it actually happened. Nobody bought a paper that day. They followed me all over town and read the news from the seat of my pants.
answer: What're you gonna do about the papers? Somebody's gotta pick 'em up.

question: Now, that's a brilliant answer. Why didn't I think of it? Our conversation could have been over long ago.
answer: Oh, yeah?

question: These seats accommodate two passengers, don't they? Move over, lady. This is a "maybe they do." Are you talking to me?
answer: Yes. Tell that man to drive slowly.

question: He got away. I suddenly found myself in the middle of the brush and not a sign of the skunk.
answer: I don't know what you're raving about, young man. And, furthermore, I'm not interested. Oh, my heavens! It's gone! What happened?

question: That cadaverous-looking yegg who sat in front of us, just up and took it. Boy, how that baby can run!
answer: What am I going to do now?

question: Don't tell me your ticket was in it? You can wire home for some money when we get to Jacksonville.
answer: Why, noI

question: Don't be a fool. You lost your bag. The company'll make good. What's your name?
answer: I don't want it reported!

question: Why, that's ridiculous! They're responsible for everything that
answer: Oh, I'm sorry Everybody's gone.

question: Yes. I hated to wake you up.
answer: No, thank you. How much time have I?

question: Don't tell me you did it on my account!
answer: You're doing a pretty sloppy job of it. I found it on the seat. You'll never get away with it, Miss Andrews. Just a spoiled brat of a rich man. You and Westley'll make an ideal team. You'll never get away with it, Miss Andrews. Your father'll stop you before you get half way to New York.

question: You must have me confused with
answer: That's right. You didn't.

question: You're not going to notify my father, are you? If you play your cards right, you might get some money out of it.
answer: I never thought of that. Mush. Mush. Send it collect.

question: Oh, you did? What am I expected to doleap for joy?
answer: I kind of half expected you to thank me.

question: Your ego is colossal.
answer: Chalk up one for your side. Now listen, you want to get to King Westley, don't you? All right, I'm here to help you. What I want is your story, exclusive. A day-to-day account. All about your mad flight to happiness. I need that story. Just between you and me I've got to have it.

question: Now isn't that just too cute? There's a brain behind that face of yours, isn't there? You've got everything nicely figured out, for yourself, including this.
answer: This? Oh, that's a matter of simple mathematics. These cabins cost two bucks a night and I'm very sorry to inform you, wifey dear, but the family purse won't stand for our having separate establishments. Oh, yeah? It's all right with me. Go on out in the storm, but I'm going to follow you, see? Yeah. And if you get tough I'll just have to turn you over to your old man right now. Savvy? Now that's my whole plot in a nutshell. A simple story for simple people. Now if you behave yourself, I'll see that you get to King Westley; if not, I'll just have to spill the beans to papa. Now which of these beds do you prefer? This one? All right. Do you mind joining the Israelites?

question: Years later his secret came out. He wore a toupee. I have an idiosyncrasy all my own. You'll notice my coat came firstthen the tiethen the shirtnow, according to Hoyle, the pants should come next. But that's where I'm different. Still with me, Brat?
answer: You haven't got a trumpet by any chance, have you?

question: Not even a mouth organ.
answer: Do you mind putting out the light?

question: You'll find the showersand thingsright back of the second cottage. Certainly, outside. All the best homes have 'em outside.
answer: I can't go out like this.

question: Like what?
answer: Like this. I have no robe.

question: Heretake mine. But make it snappy.
answer: Where is the shower?

question: I saw the little Pussinfoos girl. She's turned out quite a charming creature. Very outspoken, too. Said I looked funny. Wasn't that cute?
answer: Hurry up and get dressed. If you didn't waste so much time on that wise-cracking drummerwe'd have been through with breakfast by this time.

question: Well, I hope you're not going to dictate whom I can talk to.
answer: I know a couple of truck drivers I'd like to have you meet sometime.

question: Thank you.
answer: Egg. One eggdoughnutsblack coffee. That's your ration till lunch. Any complaints? I'd have gotten you some cream but it meant buying a whole pint.

question: Must be the Spring.
answer: I thought maybeuh"believe you me" told you a couple of snappy stories.

question: He apologized for last night. Thanks. Yes, you do. You think I'm a fool and a spoiled brat. Perhaps I am, although I don't see how I can be. People who are spoiled are accustomed to having their own way. I never have. On the contrary, I've always been told what to do and how to do it and where and with whom. Would you believe it? This is the first time I've ever been alone with a man!
answer: Yeah?

question: It's a wonder I'm not panic stricken.
answer: Um. You're doing all right.

question: Thanks. Nurses, governesses, chaperones, even body-guards. Oh, it's been a lot of fun.
answer: One consolation; you can never be lonesome.

question: It has its moments. It got to be a sort of game to try to outwit father's detectives. II did it once; actually went shopping without a body-guard. It was swell. I felt absolutely immoral. But it didn't last long. They caught up with me in a department store. I was so mad I ran out the back way and jumped into the first car I saw. Guess who was in it?
answer: Santa Claus?

question: KingKing Westley was in it.
answer: Oh. Is that how you met him?

question: Um-hm. We rode around all afternoon. Father was frantic. By 6 o'clock he was having all the rivers dragged.
answer: Say, where did you learn to dunk, in finishing school? Of course you shouldn't. You don't know how to do it. Dunking's an art. Don't let it soak so long. A dip and plop, into your mouth. If you let it soak so long, it'll get soft and fall off. It's all a matter of timing. I ought to write a book about it.

question: Thanks, professor.
answer: Just goes to show you. Twenty millions and you don't know how to dunk.

question: I'd change places with a plumber's daughter any day.
answer: Detectives! Don't look at me. I didn't marry King Westley. Sit down!

question: Say, you were pretty good. Jumping in like that. Got a brain, haven't you?
answer: You weren't so bad yourself.

question: We could start a two-person stock company. If things get toughwe can play some small town auditoriums. We'll call this one "The Great Deception."
answer: Next week "East Lynne."

question: After that "The Three Musketeers."
answer: How about Cinderellaor a real hot love story?

question: No mushy stuff. I'm running this troupe. I did! It was my idea, wasn't it?
answer: You always want to run everything.

question: If you don't like it, you can resign from the company.
answer: I refuse to resign!

question: We ain't ate nothin' since yestidday.
answer: What happened to your money?

question: Ma spent it all for the tickets. She didn't know it was gonna be so much.
answer: Going without food is bad business, son. Why didn't you ask somebody?

question: Looks like we're going to be stuck for a long time.
answer: Like to have a look at my paper? Travelin' like this, you kinda lose track of what's goin' on in the world. If you wanna get anywhere nowadays, you gotta keep in touch with all the news, is what I always say. It's a lotta dough. If I was to run across that dame, you know what I'd do?

question: What?
answer: I'd go fifty-fifty with you .

question: Why?
answer: Cause I'm a guy that don't believe in hoggin' it, see? A bird that figures that way winds up behind the eight ball, is what I always say.

question: What's on your mind? You're a pretty shrewd baby. Lucky thing, my running into you. Just the man I need. I can use a smart guy like you.
answer: Huh?

question: A gat! A gat! What's the matter with you! Gettin' yellow? Yeah ?How do I know?
answer: Oscar Shapeley.

question: Where do you live?
answer: Orange, New Jersey.

question: Got a couple of kids, huh?
answer: Yeah. Just babies.

question: You love them, don't you? If you don'tEver hear of Bugs Dooley?
answer: No.

question: Nice guy. Just like you. But he made a big mistake, one day. Got kind of talkative. Know what happened? His kid was found in the bottom of the
answer: Gee! That musta been terrible.

question: Okay. Just remember that. Now beat it.
answer: Sure. Anything you say.

question: Poor old Shapeley. You shouldn't have frightened him like that.
answer: At the rate he started, he's probably passed two state lines by this time. The exercise is good for him.

question: Yes, I noticed he was getting a little fat lately.
answer: What's the matter? I don't trust that chatterbox. First town we hit in the morning, you better wire your father.

question: Not as long as I'm alive.
answer: Okay with me, if you can stand the starvation diet.

question: What do you meanstarvation?
answer: It takes money to buy food.

question: Why, haven't you? You didn't give that boy all your money?
answer: I didn't give him anything . You were the big-hearted gal. How about wiring your father now?

question: Never! I'll get to New York if I have to starve all the way. To New York?
answer: Yeah.

question: I'm following you.
answer: Aren't you afraid of me? I wish you'd stop being playful.

question: It's the first time I've ridden "piggy-back" in years.
answer: This isn't "piggy-back."

question: Of course it is.
answer: You're crazy. And he carried you like this, I suppose.

question: Yes.
answer: I don't think there's a "piggy-back" rider in your whole family. I never knew a rich man yet who was a good "piggy-back" rider.

question: That's silly.
answer: To be a "piggy-backer" it takes complete relaxationa warm heartand a loving nature.

question: And rich people have none of those qualifications, I suppose.
answer: Not a one.

question: You're prejudiced.
answer: Show me a good "piggy-back" rider and I'll show you somebody that's human. Take Abraham Lincoln, for instancea natural "piggy-backer." Aw, nuts! Hold this a minute.

question: We're not going to sleep out here, are we?
answer: I don't know about you, but I'm going to give a fairly good imitation of it.

question: I'll get my clothes all wrinkled.
answer: What's the matter?

question: I don't want it now. I wasbut
answer: But what!

question: I was so scaredthat it scared
answer: Might get chilly later on. You've had a lot of men crazy about you, haven't you? I guess you've pretty much had your own way with them. That's your trouble mostly. You've always had your own way. That's why you're such a mess now.

question: You sound like a hobo.
answer: I am. I only work when I have to. Two years ago I got a notion and went to China. There was a war going on. Swell! After a while it got stale. I went down to Tahiti. Just lay on the beach for six months. What could be sweeter?

question: Doesn't sound very exciting.
answer: I guess not. I'd have given odds it wouldn't mean anything to you.

question: What are you thinking about?
answer: By a strange coincidence, I was thinking of you. Yeah. I was just wondering what makes dames like you so dizzy.

question: What'd you say we're supposed to be doing?
answer: Hitch-hiking.

question: Well, you've given me a very good example of the hiking If it's just the same to you, we'll sit right here till they come.
answer: No. But I've got a penknife.

question: Hayin my teeth.
answer: There it is. Better swallow it. We're not going to have any breakfast.

question: Needn't rub it in.
answer: Carrots.

question: Raw?
answer: Uh-huh. Want one? You don't think I'm going around panhandling for you.

question: I hate the horrid stuff.
answer: I wish you wouldn't talk too much. We let a car get away.

question: What if nobody stops for us?
answer: Oh, they'll stop, all right. It's a matter of knowing how to hail them.

question: You're an expert, I suppose.
answer: Expert! Going to write a book on it. Called the "Hitch-Hikers Hail."

question: There's no end to your accomplishments.
answer: You think it's simple, huh? Well, it is simple. It's all in the thumb, see? A lot of people do it

question: Tch! Tch! I'm sorry for the poor things.
answer: But the thumb always works. Different ways to do it, though. Depends on how you feel. For instance, number one is a short, jerky movement

question: Clever.
answer: Number two is a wider movementa smile goes with that onelike this.

question: You figured that all out yourself, huh?
answer: Oh, that's nothing. Now take number three, for instance. That's a pip. It's the pathetic one. When you're brokeand hungryand everything looks black. It's a long movement like this

question: Amazing.
answer: Hm? Yeah, but it's no good if you haven't got a long face with it. Something must have gone wrong. I guess I'll try number two.

question: When you get up to a hundred, wake me up.
answer: I guess maybe I won't write that book after all.

question: Yes. But look at all the fun you had. You're such a smart aleck! Nobody can do anything but you. I'll show you how to stop a carand I won't use my thumb.
answer: What're you going to do?

question: Mind your own business. You might give me a little credit.
answer: What for?

question: I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb.
answer: Why didn't you take all your clothes off? You could have stopped forty cars.

question: No. What were you going to do? Gold dig him for a meal? Eat a carrot.
answer: Never!

question: Let's get out and stretch our legs. Hey! Come onget in.
answer: What'd you give him for the car?

question: Yeah. He finally agreed to let us have a room.
answer: What about money?

question: Talked him out of it. He thinks we're going to stay a week. I'll have to think of something before morning.
answer: That's swell!

question: I'm glad you think so. If you ask me, it's foolish. I told you there's no sense in our staying here tonight. We could make New York in less than three hours.
answer: I couldn't arrive in New York at three in the morning. Everybody's in bed.

question: There you gotrustin' people again. How many times did I tell you
answer: He looked like an upright young feller to me, Ma.

question: Yeah. They're all upright till they walk out on you.
answer: Said he was gonna stay a week.

question: Mebbe.
answer: Worst comes to the worst, we got his car for security.

question: What do you want to see me for? I've served my purpose. I brought you back to King Westley, didn't I?
answer: Peter, have you ever been in love?

question: I probably did the world a great favor at that. Got two pinheads out of circulation.
answer: Haven't you ever wanted to fall in love?

question: Me?
answer: Yes. Haven't you thought about it at all? Seems to me you could make some girl wonderfully happy.

question: Joe, listen
answer: Don't "Joe" me.

question: Okay, Joe. Listenyou know I've always liked you. Anytime I could do you a great turnanytime I ran into a story that looked goodI always came running to you, didn't I? Well, I got one now. Those wires I sent you were on the level. It's the biggest scoop of the year. I'm giving it to you, Joe.
answer: You mean about the Andrews' kid?

question: That's it.
answer: A thousand dollars!

question: Don't get sore, Joe. This is something you got to do for me. I need a thousand dollarsand I need it quick. I'm in a jam. To tear down the Walls of Jericho.
answer: What!

question: Never mind . . . Listensuppose I should tell you that Ellen Andrews is going to have her marriage annulled.
answer: Huh?

question: That she's going to marry somebody else.
answer: You're drunk.

question: Would an exclusive story like that be worth a thousand bucks to you?
answer: If it's on the level.

question: Well, I got it, Joe.
answer: Who's she gonna marry?

question: Wait a minute, Joe. Use your bean. I couldn't afford to hand you a phoney yarn, like that. I'd be crazy. There isn't a newspaper in the country'd give me a job after that! I could go to jail!
answer: I'd put you there myself.

question: Sure. I wouldn't blame you, either.
answer: Who's the guy she's gonna marry?

question: I am, Joe. Yeah.
answer: Now I know you're drunk.

question: I met her on a bus coming from Miami. Been with her every minute.
answer: Well, I'll be

question: Listen, Palyou've got to get this money for me. Now. Minutes count. She's waiting for me in an auto camp outside of Philadelphia. I've got to get right back. You see, she doesn't know I'm gone.
answer: What a story!

question: That feller last night, that's who! He was gonna stay a week, huh? Well, he's skipped. Took the car with him, too. We wouldn't have known a thing about it until morning if I hadn't took that magnesia. See that. They're gone! Where's your husband, young lady
answer: Husband?

question: Yesif he is your husband.
answer: Isn't he here?

question: Well, here we are; it's all set. You're finally going to be married properly.
answer: Why; naturally, I You talk as if

question: Someday perhaps, you might even take charge. I hope so. However, that'll take care of itself. My daughter. No? Say, listenI've devoted a whole lifetime trying to tame that wildcat. Toughest job I ever tackled. Ever hear of J.P. Clarkson? Biggest man in the country, isn't he? Well, I tamed him . Got him eating out of the palm of my hand. I've browbeaten financiers, statesmen, foreign ministerssome of the most powerful people in the worldbut I've never been able to do a thing with her. She's been too much for me. I'm glad you think it's easy.
answer: What would you like to have me do?

question: Sock her!
answer: It's quite an assignment

question: Try. Do me a favor. Try. It's your only chance. And hers, too. Do that for meand maybe we'll be friends
answer: Oh, by the way, Mr Andrews, I thought of a great stunt for the reception.

question: You thought that up all by yourself, huh?
answer: Oh, no. She'll be crazy about it. Well, see you later. I'm going out on the lawn and arrange for landing space.

question: We've done that already. Autogyro! I hope he breaks his leg. OhMary
answer: Yes, sir?

question: How is she? What's the matter? Anything wrong?
answer: Oh, no, sir. No different than

question: Yes. I know. Still in the dumps, huh?
answer: Yessir. If you'll excuse me, sirshe sent me for a drink.

question: Sorry. Must have been day-dreaming.
answer: Landing on the lawn in an autogyro.

question: Oh, yes. I heard. Nothing.
answer: You've been acting so strangely since you returned. I'mI'm worried. I haven't bothered to ask you any questionsI If you have, it isn't too late. You know how I feel about him. But I want to make you happy. You gave me such a scareIwhen I couldn't find you. What is it, darling? I haven't seen you cry since you were a baby. This must be serious.

question: On the road.
answer: Who is he?

question: I don't know very much about him.
answer: Oh, come now

question: He despises everything I stand for. He thinks I'm spoiled and pampered, and selfish, and thoroughly insincere.
answer: Ridiculous!

question: He doesn't think so much of you either. He blames you for everything that's wrong about me. Thinks you raised me stupidly.
answer: Well, what are we going to do about it? Where is he? I'd like to have a talk with him.

question: It's no use, Dad. I practically threw myself at him.
answer: Well, under the circumstances, don't you think we ought to call this thing off?

question: No, I'll go through with it.
answer: But that's silly, child. Seeing how you feel, why

question: Is that his name?
answer: Yes. Peter Warne.

question: Peter Warne!
answer: Oh, please, Dad Are you going to see him?

question: I suppose so.
answer: Thanks, Mary. That's just what I need.

question: FineFine! Have him come in.
answer: How are you, Ellie? You bet we did.

question: It's up to you now. I want our life to be full of excitement, King. We'll never let up, will we? Never a dull moment. We'll get on a merry-go-round and never get off. Promise you'll never let me get off? It's the only way to live, isn't it? No time to think. We don't want to stop to think, do we? Just want to keep going.
answer: Whatever you say, darling.

question: Show him in. Mr. Warne?
answer: Yeah.

question: Come in. Sit down.
answer: That's typical of your daughter. Takes those things for granted.

question: Please understand me. When I say she didn't tell me anything about it, I mean not until a little while ago. She thinks you're entitled to anything you can get. And this is what you wantthirty-nine dollars and sixty cents?
answer: Why not? I'm not charging you for the time I wasted.

question: Yes, I knowbut
answer: What's the matter? Isn't it cheap enough? A trip like that would cost you a thousand dollars!

question: Let me get this straight. You want this thirty-nine sixty in addition to the ten thousand dollars?
answer: What ten thousand?

question: The reward. You're a peculiar chap. The average man would go after the reward. All you seem to
answer: Listen, did anybody ever make a sucker out of you? This is a matter of principle. Something you probably wouldn't understand.

question: You were taken for a buggy ride?
answer: Yeahwith all the trimmings. Now, how about the check. Do I get it?

question: Here you are. That's an evasion.
answer: If you had half the brains you're supposed to have, you'd have done it yourselflong ago.

question: Do you love her? I asked you a question. Do you love her?
answer: You bet I did.

question: You bet I did.
answer: Congratulations.

question: Same to you.
answer: Why don't you stay and watch the fun? You'll enjoy it immensely.
